thread.title: Primer on Uptown Farmers Market in Phoenix, from food to easy parking
thread.title_full: Primer on Uptown Farmers Market in Phoenix, from food to easy parking

author: Jennifer McClellan , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: Primer on Uptown Farmers Market in Phoenix, from food to easy parking
text:
Uptown is in its second year at Central Avenue and Bethany Home Road in Phoenix. Here are some of the most interesting things at the farmers market, held on Wednesdays and Saturdays. Uptown Farmers Market is a weekly farmers market on the southeast corner of Central Avenue and Bethany Home Road. It runs Wednesdays and Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. (Photo: Rachel Van Blankenship/The Republic)
16 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Great Food Finds is an occasional series where we explore the markets that give the Valley character. This time, we're at Uptown Farmers Market in Phoenix.
You can take your pick of farmers markets around metro Phoenix and find tents flush with fresh vegetables, reputable food makers and good vibes.
Uptown Farmers Market is one that has an abundance of something special: parking spaces.
Those asphalt stalls are equally as important to shoppers as they are to vendors, Uptown manager Bo Mostow said.
Uptown Farmers Market Where: Saturdays and Wednesdays at North Phoenix Baptist Church, 5757 N. Central Ave.
Saturday hours: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. October through April; 8 a.m.-noon May to September. Moves indoors in late June or early July.
Wednesday hours: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. October through June. Closes during the summer.
Details: uptownmarketaz.com .
“We have zero parking issues,” she said of the twice weekly market, held at North Phoenix Baptist Church. “Every other market is difficult to park at. They reach a point of saturation where they have to turn people away.”
That means disappointment for customers and lost business for vendors.
Mostow knows about these things. Not only is she a protégé of Cindy Gentry, who started the original Phoenix Public Market, Mostow is a mother of four who had trouble finding parking for her Chevrolet Suburban when she went to local markets.
“My kids hated it,” she said of those shopping trips.
MORE GREAT FOOD FINDS: Baiz's 99-cent bags of pita in Phoenix, Mesa | Best pretzels you’ve never had at Old Heidelberg Bakery
Mostow, 40, built a market she would want to visit in Uptown Farmers Market, in its second year at Central Avenue and Bethany Home Road.
Produce from McClendon's Select at the Uptown Farmers Market. (Photo: Rachel Van Blankenship/The Republic)
The Wednesday market has about 80 vendors and the Saturday market around 140. Some vendors come both days, while others move to another local market. Wednesdays tend to be more relaxed with a smaller crowd, while Saturdays are more boisterous and attract more families.
The market caters to different perspectives of what local food means. Vendors run the gamut from those selling peppers, mustard greens and other vegetables grown in their backyards right here in the Valley to those who farm on dozens of acres across the state.
On Saturdays, shoppers get help with their kitchen prep work at the Veggie Valet, where student chefs from the Careers through Culinary Arts Program will shred your kale, julienne your carrots and chop your onions in return for a donation. C-CAP is a national non-profit that provides scholarships and training to disadvantaged youth so they can gain the skills needed to succeed in a commercial kitchen.
It doesn’t matter if you stop by Uptown Farmers Market on a weekday or weekend. You’ll always find a mix of Arizona farmers, food makers, kitchen craftsmen and garden gurus. And you’ll see people with dogs, strollers and tote bags.
Here are some of the most interesting things we found at Uptown Farmers Market.
No-hassle payments Arizona Living Greens LLC offers a variety of fresh-cut herbs and greens at the Uptown Farmers Market. (Photo: Rachel Van Blankenship/The Republic)
The payment system at Uptown is a little different, too. You don’t have to carry a slip of paper around or wait in lines to pay when you’re done shopping. Instead, you purchase tokens from the informational booth at the start of your trip and use those to buy directly from vendors. Tokens come in $10 increments. If your purchase is $9, then the vendor gives you back $1. So, there’s no worry about not using the full token amount.
You can pay with cash anywhere, and more than half of the vendors take credit cards.
Good to know: Also, the market accepts Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) and Women, Infants and Children (WIC) checks.
Produce and protein McClendon’s Select brings baskets, bushels and bins filled with organic fruits and vegetables. You’ll find all the staple crops along with fun items like crimson gold apples, blood oranges, watermelon radishes, Romanesco, purple potatoes and orange cauliflower.
AZCENTRAL
Things To Do app: Get the best in events, dining and travel right on your device
“McClendon is McClendon. He’s been at it a long time and he knows exactly what he’s doing. He has a huge following,” Mostow said.
You can get your fill of microgreens from Arizona Living Greens, which sells freshly cut sprouts of pac choi, arugula and mustard greens. TJ Farms offers fresh-from-the-soil beets, butternut squash and cucumbers.
Alaskan Pride Seafoods sells salmon, sablefish and halibut, while JH Grass Fed has beef, lamb and pork.
Also check out: Indoor dairy market with goods from Danzeisen Dairy, among others.
Take-home food Jason Dwight runs the Persepshen truck with his wife Katherine at the Uptown Farmers Market. (Photo: Rachel Van Blankenship/The Republic)
Phoenix native Jason Dwight and his wife, Katherine, run Persepshen. The chef-and-pastry-chef couple worked in kitchens for Kevin Binkley and Aaron Chamberlin and then branched out on their own. They bake breads and smoke meats in a wood-fired oven that Dwight built on the back of a military trailer, part of which is used as the display case at the market.
RELATED: New restaurants: Chronic Tacos, Modern Market | Top food, drink events in February | Phoenix named America's best pizza city
Expect goodies like an organic pumpernickel pretzel stuffed with guanciale, borrek stuffed with feta and greens, and jars of whole-grain mustard. You’ll find loaves of crusty bread at Mediterra Bread and Noble Bread, along with sweets from Baker Thirteen and Hunger Bomb Cookies.
“What you buy here is going to be bad in a week,” said Mostow, meaning there are no preservatives in the homemade food.
Also check out: Locally roasted coffee from Blue House Coffee Goods; handmade dips from Los Muertos Salsa; humane snacks from Fluffy Vegans; mesquite blossom honey from Sun Valley Bees.
Ready-to-eat food The shrimp street tacos from Shrimp Viche Man at the Uptown Farmers Market. (Photo: Rachel Van Blankenship/The Republic)
Uptown patrons can buy food from vendors and rotating food trucks and then eat at tables that are set up under shade tents. On Wednesdays, grab a Nutella beignet from the Beignet Babe’s booth. She also serves a sweet play on biscuits and gravy: a beignet stuffed with scrambled eggs and cheese and topped with sausage gravy. The Shrimp Viche Man grills shrimp for tacos on Wednesdays, while you can get chicken green chile tamales from The Tamale Store on Wednesdays and Saturdays.
Also check out: Chocolate chip waffle topped with cookies from the Top It Waffle truck; a Mason jar of coffee from Mama’s Cold Brew; chicken pot pie from Squarz Bakery and Cafe; salty-sweet popcorn from Bravo Tango Kettle Corn.
Other than food Harold Shay, owner of Arizona Adirondack, sells red cedar garden chairs, chaise loungers, side tables, gliders and bistro sets in his Glendale shop. Keep your clothes clean in the kitchen with an apron for you or your child from Aprons by Lee. Grind garlic, ginger, chocolate and cheese on a (dishwasher-safe) stone grater from Gourmet Graters.
Also check out: Wood cutting boards from Artisan Cutting & Serving Boards; handcrafted raised garden beds from Above Ground Gardens; Pacific coral necklaces from Unique Naturals; bars of soap from Wild Clover Botanicals.
Reach the reporter at jennifer.mcclellan@arizonarepublic.com or 602-444-8546. Follow on Twitter @JenMcClel .

Saturday hours: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. October through April; 8 a.m.-noon May to September. Moves indoors in late June or early July.
Wednesday hours: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. October through June. Closes during the summer.
Details: uptownmarketaz.com .
